Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Field Theory, Atomic Physics and General Relativity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will attempt to combine relativistic quantum theory of nanoscale phenomena with the concepts of general relativity, a theory primarily designed to cover astrophysical phenomena. One of the aims is to study the consequences for relativistic geodesy, where one uses tiny frequency shifts in atomic transitions, as a function of the altitude of an atomic clock, in order to map out the Earth's surface. To accomplish this task, modern computer algorithms will be developed in concert with an improved understanding of quantum field theories to advance our quantitative understanding of quantum mechanical bound states of atoms. Only by combining quantum field theory with the notion of curved spacetime can our current understanding of the very large be reconciled with our current understanding of the very small. This project will continue and extend the PI's explorations of this synthesis of two world views. The supervision of graduate students and the completion of an extensive monograph on the subject matter will complement the research program.

The research planned for this project will cover theoretical physics research in various related fields, including extensions of the Dirac equation to curved space-time, pseudo-Hermitian extensions of Dirac theory, the use of highly powerful parallel computer algorithms for the calculation of atomic properties. Existing discrepancies between theory and experiment (the so-called muonic hydrogen/proton radius puzzle and the enhancement of internal pair creation in the decay of 8Be) will be analyzed theoretically, and higher-order corrections will be studied. The Dirac formalism will be augmented by a coupling of the bispinor to curved space-time, with special emphasis on consequences for relativistic geodesy. Finally, investigations on atom-surface contact interactions and non-contact friction effects will complement the research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is often being said that physics, on the fundamental level,  
offers only limited possibilities for breakthroughs or advances  
that lift the science to an entirely new level. Within the NSF  
project "Quantum Field Theory, Atomic Physics and General  
Relativity" (NSF PHY-1710856), we have been trying to "do the  
impossible". Progress can be reported on a number of subprojects.  
(1.) Let us first consider a potentially observed novel particle,  
an addition to the so-called Standard Model of Fundamental  
Interactions, conceivably found at a relatively small rest-mass  
energy of only 16.7 MeV (therefore tentatively called the "X17"  
particle), in hitherto unconfirmed experiments in Hungary (at the  
Nuclear Physics Laboratory of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences).  
It is unclear at present if the new particle exists or if the  
signal seen in the experiment is spurious.  However, if the  
particle does exist, then, in atomic systems, as we were able to  
show, the particle could be detected in high-precision  
experiments on muonic atoms. The X17 would show up in small, but  
important shifts of a frequency interval known as the hyperfine  
splitting. All other atomic-physics effects caused by the  
putative X17 particle would be too tiny to be observed under  
realistic assumptions. We were able to show that the mass range  
of 17 MeV (give or take) is a rather unfavorable mass range for  
the generation of sizeable effects in atomic physics, because in  
this case, the range of the effective potential generated by the  
new particle is commensurate with the extent of the nuclear  
charge distribution, and thus the effects of the X17 in atomic  
systems are "hidden" (to a large extent) in the so-called  
finite-size correction which describes the effect of the finite  
nuclear charge distribution on the spectrum. The notable  
exception is the hyperfine splitting in muonic systems, where the  
"normal" orbiting particle (the electron) is replaced by its  
heavy "cousin", the muon. (2.) The second sub-area where  
substantial progress has been achieved, concerns the limits of  
the predictive power of perturbation theory, as set forth by the  
ever-increasing difficulties to evaluate large-order Feynman  
graphs.  The famous American physicist Richard Feynman  
discovered, in 1949, that certain perturbative processes in  
quantum field theory can be interpreted in terms of graphical  
structures, that describe, schematically, the travel paths and  
the interactions of fundamental particles. All important  
processes in modern quantum field theories are amenable to such  
graphical representations. The higher the order of perturbation  
theory, the higher is the so-called loop order at which the  
calculations have to be performed.  The problem, though, is that,  
as we go higher in perturbation theory, the computational  
complexity increases dramatically, as the number of graphs grows  
factorially (faster than any power) of the so-called loop order,  
i.e., of the order of perturbation theory.  Using modern  
quantum-field theoretical techniques, we were able to show that,  
as the number of loops increases, the evaluation of the  
higher-order corrections becomes easier, because one can map the  
problem onto a different domain in the physical parameter space  
of the coupling constant, solve the evaluation of the large-order  
Feynman graphs using so-called instanton calculus in the unstable  
domain, and then, transform back to the evaluation of the Feynman  
graphs that one had initially desired. Specifically, we were able  
to show that correlation functions in so-called phi-4 theories  
with an internal symmetry group are amenable to a very accurate  
large-order analysis, in which we also evaluated corrections to  
the large-order asymptotics of the perturbative coefficients.  
These compare favorably with perturbative calculations to the  
seventh or eighth loop-order and can be used in order to  
interpolate between the perturbative and nonperturbative domain  
of a quantum field theory, thus overcoming the predictive limits  
of perturbation theory.  This result is very important for the  
understanding of precise quantum field theories like quantum  
electrodynamics, on which modern atomic physics is based.  The  
research has been described in an article published in the  
magazine "Research Outreach". Further developments: Both of the  
above aspects are but two highlights from a long list of research  
results achieved under the grant PHY-1710856. Another example  
concerns the most accurate limits on so-called Lorentz-violating  
parameters for neutrinos; such parameters describe conceivable  
deviations of the kinematics of neutrino particles from the  
expected "Einsteinian" behavior. Specifically, we discovered a  
novel decay process which would otherwise affect  
Lorentz-violating neutrinos traveling from galaxy to galaxy; the  
additional decay process sets the precise limits.  Another  
highlight: The original proposal called for the investigation of  
gravitational effects on antimatter. We are happy to report that  
the proof of the equivalence principle for spin-1/2 antimatter,  
for general dynamic space-time backgrounds, could be completed in  
2020. This proof opened the possibility for additional  
interesting experiments testing a conceivable charge asymmetry of  
antimatter, which had not been envisaged previously and were  
devised in 2021. (795 words)

The second sub-area where substantial progress has been achieved, concerns the limits of the predictive power of perturbation theory, as set forth by the ever-increasing difficulties to evaluate large-order Feynman graphs. The famous American physicist Richard Feynman discovered, in 1949, that certain perturbative processes in quantum field theory can be interpreted in terms of graphical structures, that describe, schematically, the travel paths and the interactions of fundamental particles. This result is very important for the understanding of precise quantum field theories like quantum electrodynamics, on which modern atomic physics is based. We are happy to report that the proof of the equivalence principle for spin-1/2 antimatter, for general dynamic space-time backgrounds, could be completed in 2020.
